result.execSummary:
The defendant Eric D Ward* was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Status conference on June 17, 2016 at 01:15 pm.

Defendant Eric D Ward in court with attorney Helmi Hamad.  Robert Scott Repischak appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court Reporter: Patricia Schaefer.
The State is not prepared to proceed. The civil process service has been on vacation and Mr. Repischak has not been able to get confirmation of service. Victims and witnesses have moved and it's been difficult to find them. Defense moves to dismiss.

BTC: Matter will be left on the trial calendar and is to be put on set on later this week so the State can report its findings  Status conference scheduled for June 17, 2016 at 01:15 pm.

Deft is in custody in Kenosha County but Mr. Hamad hasn't had the time to inform the State of the deft's location. Defense is ready to proceed w/o deft being here. The State objects. The State has indicated that 3 witnesses moved and left no forwarding address. State asked for assistance locating these individuals and RPD was successful in finding them; subpoenas have been resent. The State asks for adj
